vendor: Darena Solutions LLC dba Darena Health (shared certification platform)

access.description: The registered URL at www.darenasolutions.com returns a 301 redirect to darena.health (domain rebranding), then the destination page contains a JavaScript redirect from /meldrx-onc-hti1-certified to /onc-hti1-certified. A browser is required to follow the JS redirect. Once loaded, the #b10-EHI-Export-Documentation anchor exists in the page and scrolls to the relevant section. A Squarespace newsletter popup must be dismissed. The EHI section is short — just two sentences pointing to the Swagger API docs and the FHIR Bulk Data standard.

product_context.description: Darena Health (formerly MeldRx, BlueButtonPRO) is NOT an EHR — it is a middleware FHIR API compliance platform. It provides pre-certified ONC modules that other EHR vendors integrate with to achieve certification. The platform is a multi-tenant cloud SaaS where EHR vendors push patient data into Darena's FHIR data store, and Darena handles certified API access and EHI export. Eleven different EHR products from eleven different developers all share this single Darena certification, covering a remarkable range of specialties: dermatology (EZDERM), behavioral health (PIMSY Platinum, Office Anywhere), physical therapy (Raintree), radiology (eRAD RIS), substance abuse treatment (WITS), epidemiology (Epi-Management), and general ambulatory (UnifiMD, Clinicmind, Doctorsoft, Amrita). Each of these downstream EHR products has its own native data stores with billing, scheduling, messaging, document management, and specialty-specific data. The critical issue is that the Darena-based EHI export can only export data that each EHR has mapped and pushed into the Darena FHIR platform — which is likely limited to clinical data needed for USCDI/FHIR compliance.
product_context.broader_product_name: Multiple products (Amrita HIS, Clinicmind, Doctorsoft EHR, EZDERM, Epi-Management, Office Anywhere, PIMSY Platinum, Raintree, UnifiMD, WITS, eRAD RIS)

export_approach.description: Darena's EHI export uses FHIR Bulk Export (HL7 FHIR Bulk Data STU1.0.1) for structured data, with DocumentReference resources as a catch-all for non-FHIR content including C-CDA documents. The export is API-based, not a traditional file download — users interact with the FHIR $Export operation via the API. The Swagger API shows an 'Export' operation in the FHIR operations enum. The internal data model (MyMipsScore.Core.Models) maps to approximately 60 models covering standard clinical FHIR resources: Patient, Allergy, Medication, Immunization, Observation, Procedure, CarePlan, CareTeam, Coverage, Communication, DiagnosticReport, Document, Goal, Device, ServiceRequest, Specimen, and related models. Notably absent from the internal data model are ANY billing/financial models, scheduling/appointment models, or audit trail models. This strongly suggests the export is limited to clinical FHIR resources and cannot include the full EHI that the downstream EHR products store.

documentation_quality.description: The EHI export documentation is extremely minimal — just two sentences on the ONC certification page, pointing to the Swagger API docs and the FHIR Bulk Data standard. The Swagger API spec (646 KB, OpenAPI 3.0) does provide schema-level and field-level detail for the 298 API components, including Darena's internal data models and FHIR types. However, there is no EHI-specific data dictionary, no documentation of what FHIR resource types are actually populated for any given EHR integration, no description of what data the export includes or excludes, and no product-specific documentation for any of the 11 downstream EHR products. A developer looking at this documentation would know the API structure but would have no idea what data to expect from a given product's EHI export.

ehi_coverage.overall_assessment: The Darena Health EHI export is fundamentally limited by its middleware architecture. As a FHIR API platform that sits between EHRs and their users, Darena can only export data that has been pushed into it by the upstream EHR. Darena's internal data model covers standard clinical FHIR resources (approximately 60 models), plus Coverage and Communication. However, it has ZERO billing/financial models (no Claim, ChargeItem, Payment, Invoice), ZERO scheduling models (no Appointment, Schedule, Slot), and ZERO audit models (no AuditEvent, Provenance). The downstream EHR products — many of which are full practice management systems with billing, scheduling, and patient portals — almost certainly store data in these categories that cannot be exported through Darena. The DocumentReference catch-all could theoretically contain billing statements or other documents as attached files, but this would be PDF/binary content, not structured machine-readable data. This is a structural gap inherent to the middleware certification model: the certified module (Darena) doesn't have access to the full data stored by the product it's a part of.

clinical.evidence: Internal data models include: Allergy, Medication, MedicationSupply, Immunization, Observation, Procedure, Problem (Condition), CarePlan, CareTeam, Goal, DiagnosticReport, Device, Specimen, ServiceRequest. Enums include clinical status values, verification statuses, and coded value systems (ICD-10, RxNorm, SNOMED, LOINC via CodingSystem enum). This covers core USCDI clinical data classes.

secure_messages.evidence: A Communication model exists with CommunicationType enum values of 'ProviderToProvider' and 'PatientToProvider', plus participants and status fields. However, this appears to be the FHIR Communication resource with minimal payload — it's unclear whether actual message content/body text is included, and whether this represents the full messaging history from downstream EHR patient portals.

billing_financial.evidence: Searched all 298 schema names for charge, claim, payment, billing, invoice, transaction, revenue — NONE found. Darena's internal data model has no billing or financial models whatsoever. The FHIR ResourceType enum includes Claim, ChargeItem, Invoice, ExplanationOfBenefit, etc. (as part of the full FHIR R4 spec), but these don't appear in Darena's actual internal models, suggesting they are not implemented. Many downstream products (Clinicmind, Raintree, PIMSY, eRAD RIS) are practice management systems with extensive billing capabilities.

insurance_coverage.evidence: Coverage model exists with memberId, subscriberId, status (CoverageStatus enum), relationship (CoverageRelationship enum), payor (CoveragePayor enum), and classes (CoverageClass enum). This covers basic insurance coverage data but likely lacks detailed authorization, eligibility, and benefits information.

appointments_scheduling.evidence: Searched all schema names for appointment, schedule, slot, booking — NONE found in Darena's internal models. The FHIR ResourceType enum includes Appointment, Schedule, and Slot but these are not reflected in Darena's data model. Downstream products like Raintree, Clinicmind, and PIMSY all have appointment scheduling features.

documents_images.evidence: Document model exists with DocumentType enum (DischargeSummary, ConsultNote, HistoryAndPhysicalNote, ProgressNote, ProcedureNote, DiagnosticImagingStudy, LaboratoryReport, PathologyStudy, SurgicalOperationNote, EmergencyDepartmentNote, SummaryOfEpisodeNote). DocumentReference FHIR resource is also supported as a catch-all for non-FHIR content including C-CDA. However, the document types are clinical notes — no scanned documents, faxes, or patient-uploaded content types.

audit_trails.evidence: No audit-related models found in Darena's internal data model. No AuditEvent or Provenance models. While Darena is certified for (d)(2) Auditable Events and (d)(3) Audit Reports, these appear to be features of the Darena platform itself, not data exported to users.

issues: Darena Health is a middleware FHIR API platform, not an EHR — the EHI export can only contain data that upstream EHR vendors have pushed into the platform, which is almost certainly a subset of their full data.
Eleven different EHR products from eleven different developers all share this identical, minimal EHI export documentation with no product-specific information.
The EHI export documentation consists of only two sentences, with no data dictionary, no field definitions, and no description of what data categories are included or excluded.
Zero billing/financial data models exist in Darena's internal schema, despite many downstream products being full practice management systems with billing capabilities.
Zero scheduling/appointment data models exist, despite many downstream products having appointment scheduling features.
Zero audit trail models exist in the export, despite Darena being certified for auditable events and audit reports.
The registered URL requires a JavaScript redirect to reach the actual content — cannot be accessed via simple HTTP request.
The FHIR Bulk Export approach means the export is limited to data that fits FHIR R4 resource structures, which inherently excludes many types of EHR-specific data.
The DocumentReference catch-all for non-FHIR content is vaguely described and it's unclear what data actually flows through it for any given product.

There is a structural compliance concern: b(10) requires export of all EHI stored by 'the product, of which the Health IT Module is a part' — but the Darena module likely cannot access the full data stores of the downstream EHR products it is integrated with.

downloaded_files.description: OpenAPI 3.0 specification for Darena Health APIs (v16). Contains 81 API paths and 298 schema components including Darena's internal data models (60 clinical models) and FHIR types. This is the primary technical documentation for understanding what data the EHI export can contain.
ONC HTI-1 certification page containing the EHI Export Documentation section (two sentences), certified criteria list, cost transparency table, and real-world testing plan links.

summary: Darena Health is a middleware FHIR API compliance platform — not an EHR — that 11 different EHR vendors use for ONC certification. The EHI export uses FHIR Bulk Export with DocumentReference as a catch-all for non-FHIR content. Darena's internal data model covers ~60 clinical models but has zero billing, scheduling, or audit trail models, creating significant coverage gaps for downstream products that are full practice management systems. The documentation is minimal (two sentences), with no product-specific data dictionary for any of the 11 certified products.
notes: This is a notable example of the 'shared certification' pattern, where a middleware vendor provides a pre-certified FHIR module that multiple EHR vendors embed. While this is efficient for certification, it creates a structural problem for b(10) compliance: the certified module (Darena) sits outside the EHR's native data store and can only export data that has been explicitly pushed to it. For the typical integration, this means USCDI-level clinical data gets exported, but billing, scheduling, messaging, audit trails, and specialty-specific data that lives only in the EHR's native database does not. The FHIR ResourceType enum in the Swagger spec includes the full FHIR R4 resource list (including Claim, Appointment, AuditEvent, etc.) but Darena's internal data model — which reflects what the platform actually stores — lacks models for these resource types. The DocumentType enum is limited to 11 clinical note types (DischargeSummary, ConsultNote, ProgressNote, etc.) with no billing documents, insurance forms, or administrative records. The Communication model exists and could theoretically represent portal messages, but it has minimal fields and it's unclear whether actual message content flows through it.
